comments.commentBody: Although they both agree on funding endless wars.

The President holds all the cards. He should not fold by accepting McConnell's attempt to save the GOP leadership's skins. That would be an endless legislative disaster; nobody would ever believe another thing the President says; and he would surely lose the next election.

McConnell and Boehner should be given the choice of either splitting the GOP from within by whipping the House into line, or else destroying the GOP brand with the voters by not raising the ceiling -- a disaster that would probably last only 24 hours and a short market dip, until reality hits the Tea Party right between the eyes.

If certain banks and stock brokerages were "too big to fail" from Congress' perspective, then why isn't the U.S. Government "too big to fail" and deserving of their figuring out a way to keep their ship of state afloat. The Constitution makes the Congress responsible for running the government, not the President. We the people are all assuming that sometime in the next week Congress will get its act together and prevent disaster.

But at what cost? Investors both in and out of the United States were antsy about us as an investment before all this started. This fiscal insensibility is not going to improve our appeal. And what is it that everyone agrees is needed to get the US economy moving again? Consumer confidence. How can any consumer have confidence in an economy that is run by the big money interests and for the big money interests?

And please, before we stop Social Security checks for the needy elderly, could we please stop checks for the arrogant Congress?

President Obama needs to dust off his soapbox and explain that taxing the wealthy fairly and deficit reduction to Americans and ask them to demand that congress accept his plan. About 20 hard facts and a sense of humour should do it. Profiteers have made a killing off of the Republican policy in Iraq, the Republican government that allowed the balloon mortgage scam, and Republican policy which allowed the BP disaster and also failed New Orleans. They want more of this. They don't care about American lives and are greasing their palms now just thinking about how to profit again while ordinary Americans twist in the wind. Ordinary Americans need to step up now and demand a timely deficit reduction deal before the end of July. They need hard examples from their near future to help them understand why they must take a stand now.

Republican's are fiscally conservative, yeah right! LOL

Cost of Bush/Republican war in Iraq $3 Trillion
Cost of Bush/Republican Medicare Drub Plan $550 Billion
Plan to pay for it all, none.

"Almost lost in the tax debate with Republicans is how much Mr. Obama has conceded to them this year on spending cuts, including for those entitlement programs Democrats favor."

Why doesn't Obama just declare himself the leader of the moderate wing of the Republican Party and be done with it?
Please don't take away his US citizenship, otherwise we in Australia will have to take him back.
Dear Rupert,forget about hiring fancy lawyers. What you need is a bail bondsman.

#122, Rupert's media outlets have expended plenty of energy denigrating the NYT and other legitimate media...as well as denigrating the police,the president, the Democratic party, laws regulating public behavior, etc, etc.  As far as Fox viewers organizing a boycott of the NYT, it won't succeed.  Fox viewers believe the NYT is too "emm ess emm" or "librul", so they don't read it.
murdoch is pure evil-all the lies on fox as well are disgusting.most civilized countries would not put up with it.what is it with america?free speech? fairytale believers?wake up!many will not.

I just wish this hadn't happened. I would have done anything to have been the person the child asked for directions. I would have taken his hand, found his camp and located his mom for him.

This is just so, so sad. What a sweet looking boy.
Kerry would have been a very good president.  Unfortunately he was a lousy candidate.

Just think of how much grief this country would have been spared if Senator Kerry had been elected President in 2004.  Instead, the country was fooled (i.e. swift boated) into voting for a con artist instead of a hero and a statesman.

The worst part of John Kerry is that he had introduced a bill in the senate to legitimize the U.S. attack on Libya. He knows very well that the Libyan rebels are the bunch of mercenaries, robbers and plunderers on the payroll of France and who are killing indiscriminately the innocent civilians of Libya. I don't understand what that did it make him to support such a civil war at the cost American taxpayers money. The overwhelming majority of the New York Times Bloggers had disapproved his initiatives.
John Kerry represents an old school of thoughts. At the present situation when our economy is in the grip of meltdown, a country like China is balking at our performance, we don't need a senator of his caliber. It's time that he should resign and serve his neighborhood or church.
President Obama always used or abused an wooded owl like him. It's time to go.
@Drake: I think there is room for both policy and personality. The later tends to mold the former.

Kerry's 'what we say goes' attitude is a far cry above the pathetic and seedy prose in certain policy circuits singularly devoted to inciting violence, but still, it's a ways from a truce achieve in practice. We need to call peace where and when we see it, and then move out, now that Bin Laden is finished off.

John Kerry should have easily defeated President Bush in 2004, but failed to do it. So even if he becomes Secretaty of State someday, I will be surprised if he can deliver.

Any deplomacy with out some arm twisting will not work with these Muslim countries.

Obama is "transformational?"  He has pursued and expanded many of the same policies of the GWB administration.  What has been accomplished with all of the money that has been spent, particularly in Afghanistan?
The picture of him is worth a 1000 words: he is a dork who has failed at everything except clinging to his office and marrying way up.

Maybe a different perspective is required here.  Diplomacy pays off over a longer period than the 24 hour news cycle or the endless presidential election cycle or a single presidential administration.  It also mostly does not pay off in the specifically desired immediate goal.  Doesn't mean it fails.

Leave those people alone.

That is the best diplomacy.

I lean left. I voted for Kerry in 2004. But he's a great example of the sclerosis affecting our legislative branch. Entitled, rich and dumb as a frickin' post. I can only imagine what the Afghanis think of him...

This article reflects how public servants, such as John Kerry and Al Gore, can last beyond politics. Even though both lost the opportunity to become president, both have succeeded beyond that of the person who 'defeated' them. It makes me wonder how the world, especially America's role in it, would have differed had certain elections gone differently? Would these excellent and necessary statesmen have been as successful had they won election? Regardless, I am glad to know that they are fighting for what they believe in - and what is right - much more than the "other guy".
"...that diplomacy fails most of the time." Geez, I hope not. That's an expensive pile of masonry and expertise they have down there.
John Kerry is hardly an All-American. He's loaded, which certainly does NOT apply to the 95% of the rest of us born in this country.
